Question:
Consider a grid of size 4 x 4 (i.e. sixteen squares), where all squares should get a color. The colored grid should meet the following conditions:
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?
Human Solution:
W B G R
R Y W B
B G R Y
Y W B G
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Recast the requirement “no colour repeats in a row, column, or diagonal” as a Latin-square–type constraint (a 4 × 4 array in which each permitted colour may occur at most once in every straight line). — Creative  

2. Observe that only one colour must appear exactly four times, the same as the number of rows and columns.  Decide to use that colour (blue) as an anchor that will be placed once in every row and every column, giving a structural skeleton for the grid. — Creative  

3. Position the four blues in a simple cyclic pattern—(row 1, col 2), (row 2, col 4), (row 3, col 1), (row 4, col 3)—so that no two blues share a row, column, or diagonal, and each row/column is left with three empty squares to be filled. — Rudimentary  

4. Choose a cyclic Latin-square pattern for the other four colours (white, green, red, yellow) so that each of them will also appear once in every row and column and not clash on the diagonals. — Creative  

5. Fill the remaining twelve squares according to that pattern:  
   • Row 1: W __ G R  
   • Row 2: R Y W __  
   • Row 3: __ G R Y  
   • Row 4: Y W __ G  
   (the blanks are the already-placed blues). — Rudimentary  

6. Verify counts (B 4, R 3, W 3, G 3, Y 3) and check all rows, columns, and diagonals to confirm that no colour repeats, yielding the final grid:  
   W B G R  
   R Y W B  
   B G R Y  
   Y W B G. — Rudimentary

4. Choose a cyclic Latin-square pattern for the other four colours (white, green, red, yellow) so that each of them will also appear once in every row and column and not clash on the diagonals. — Creative

   W B G R

   B G R Y  
   Y W B G. — Rudimentary']

Question: There are 2008 eggs lying in front of you. I am also with you waiting to start the game. The goal of the game is to be the person to take that very last egg (or eggs) to win. You and I can each only take between 1 and 100 eggs at a time. You go first. How many eggs must you take initially in order to always win (assuming we both play perfectly)?
Hint: By a perfect game, that means over any two turns, the sum of the number of eggs  you and I take is the same (except of course, excluding the initial move you make).
Human Solution:
89 eggs.
In order to see this, look at the smallest way possible to guarantee a win; you leave me with 101 eggs. If I take 1 egg, you take all 100; if I take 100 eggs, you take the last one. Therefore you would always win.
If you try with 202, I can take from 1 to 100, so there is 201 to 102 left. Then you would take 100 or 1 egg(s) in order to leave me with 101 again. By simple analysis, you must take 101 eggs over two rounds in order to get down to 101.
19*101 = 1919, so we must take 2008-1919 = 89 eggs to start off with a multiple of 101.
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Recognize that the key “target” position is to leave the opponent with exactly 101 eggs, because the allowed moves (1–100 eggs) let the current player respond with the complementary number to reach 101 and take the last egg(s).  (Creative)  

2. Verify the 101-egg target: if the opponent takes 1 egg, you take 100; if the opponent takes 100 eggs, you take 1; in every case you finish the game.  (Rudimentary)  

3. Generalize the idea into an invariant: after each of your turns you should leave a multiple of 101 eggs (101, 202, 303, …), guaranteeing the above response works on every subsequent pair of moves.  (Creative)  

4. Note that because the opponent can remove 1–100 eggs, you must remove the complementary amount so that together both removals total 101 each full cycle; hence over your first two moves you will have removed 101 eggs.  (Rudimentary)  

5. Find the largest multiple of 101 that does not exceed the starting total of 2008 eggs: 19 × 101 = 1919.  (Rudimentary)  

6. Determine the needed first move to reach that multiple: 2008 − 1919 = 89 eggs. Therefore, you must take 89 eggs initially to ensure victory.  (Rudimentary)

Creative ', ' 2

2. Verify the 101-egg target: if the opponent takes 1 egg, you take 100; if the opponent takes 100 eggs, you take 1; in every case you finish the game.  (Rudimentary)  

3. Generalize the idea into an invariant: after each of your turns you should leave a multiple of 101 eggs (101, 202, 303, …), guaranteeing the above response works on every subsequent pair of moves.  (Creative)  

4. Note that because the opponent can remove 1–100 eggs, you must remove the complementary amount so that together both removals total 101 each full cycle; hence over your first two moves you will have removed 101 eggs.  (Rudimentary)  

5. Find the largest multiple of 101 that does not exceed the starting total of 2008 eggs: 19 × 101 = 1919.  (Rudimentary)  

6. Determine the needed first move to reach that multiple: 2008 − 1919 = 89 eggs. Therefore, you must take 89 eggs initially to ensure victory.  (Rudimentary)']

Question:
In the purely fictitious land of Fiddledeboox, the Minister of Finance emerged from a top-level meeting.   Reporters had gathered to hear his announcement about either an increase or a decrease in either wages, subsidies or tax levels.
It was widely known that this Minister [M] told the truth to reporters [R] only once in every three statements.
M:  Well, I can tell you that it's about subsidies.
R:  Are they going down again?
M:  Nothing is going down.
R:  So it's good news for the people?
M:  Of course.  Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase.
While others jostled to ask the next question, one logically minded newshound was already leaving with the hot headline news.
From the Minister's three statements above, can you also deduce the truth?
Hint:
Assume each statement, in turn, to be true.  Then examine the truth or otherwise of the others.
Or check the statements in the light of each of the six possibilities.
Human Solution:
It was a tax increase.
Solution:
Remember that only one statement can be true.
If (1) is true then either (2) or (3) will be true as well.  So (1) is a lie.
If (3) is true, either (1) or (2) would be also true.  So (3) is a lie.
If (2) is true, it must be either wages or taxes going up or (1) would be true.  It cannot be wages, making (3) true, so taxes are increasing.
There are other ways of deducing this gloomy news.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Note that the Minister tells the truth once in every three statements, so among the three quoted statements exactly one must be true.  
2. Assume statement (1) “it’s about subsidies” is that single true statement.  If the measure really concerns subsidies, then either statement (2) (“Nothing is going down”) or statement (3) (“Either subsidies are going down or there will be a wage increase”) would also turn out true, giving more than one true statement.  Contradiction ⇒ statement (1) is false.  
3. Assume statement (3) is the only true statement.  If subsidies go down, then the topic is subsidies, making statement (1) true as well; if wages go up, then “nothing is going down,” making statement (2) true.  In either sub-case two statements become true.  Contradiction ⇒ statement (3) is false.  
4. Since statements (1) and (3) cannot be true, statement (2) “Nothing is going down” must be the single true statement.  
5. From the truth of statement (2) we learn that whatever the government is changing must be increasing rather than decreasing.  
6. If wages were the thing increasing, the clause “there will be a wage increase” would make statement (3) true, violating the one-truth rule.  Therefore wages are not increasing.  
7. The only remaining quantity that can be increasing without contradicting anything else is taxes; hence the change being announced is a tax increase.

Creative ', ' 0

If subsidies go down, then the topic is subsidies, making statement (1) true as well; if wages go up, then “nothing is going down,” making statement (2) true.  In either sub-case two statements become true.  Contradiction ⇒ statement (3) is false.  
4. Since statements (1) and (3) cannot be true, statement (2) “Nothing is going down” must be the single true statement.  
5. From the truth of statement (2) we learn that whatever the government is changing must be increasing rather than decreasing.  
6. If wages were the thing increasing, the clause “there will be a wage increase” would make statement (3) true, violating the one-truth rule.  Therefore wages are not increasing.  
7. The only remaining quantity that can be increasing without contradicting anything else is taxes; hence the change being announced is a tax increase.']

Question:
There are 3 numbers 0-9.
Eric knows the product and says, "I know the numbers."
Then, everyone is told that one digit is exactly one greater than another.
Then, Luke is told one of the numbers and says, "Eric lied."
Then you are told the numbers add up to 11.
What are the numbers?
Human Solution:
0, 5, 6
Eric knows the product and claimed that he knows the numbers.
Luke is told a number and then he knows Eric lied.
If Luke had received an 8, the combination could be 8,8,8, which is the only combination that multiplies to 512; Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 6, the combination could be 6,7,7 which is the only combination that multiplies to 294, so Luke wouldn't know Eric lied.
If Luke received 2 or 7; 2x7x7=98.
4 or 5; 4x5x5=100.
3 or 9; 3x9x9=243.
1; 1x1x1=1.
Luke would only know that Eric lied if Luke was given a 0.
Therefore one of the digits is 0.
The remaining two digits must add to 11 because 11-0=11.
Two of the digits are one apart so that leaves:
0 & 1 + 10
5 & 6 + 0
However, 10 isn't an option so it must be 0, 5, 6.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Interpret Eric’s statement: he could only “know the numbers” from the product if that product is produced by exactly one valid triple; therefore, for Luke to be sure Eric lied, the digit Luke sees must make such uniqueness impossible. (Creative)  
2. Check each digit 1–9 and show that for each one there exists at least one triple whose product is unique (e.g., 8,8,8 → 512; 6,7,7 → 294; 2,7,7 → 98; 4,5,5 → 100; 3,9,9 → 243; 1,1,1 → 1). Hence, seeing any of these digits would not let Luke conclude Eric lied. (Rudimentary)  
3. Observe that if Luke sees a 0, every triple containing 0 has product 0, so product = 0 can never single out one triple; thus Eric could not have been certain, and Luke would instantly know Eric lied. (Creative)  
4. Deduce that one of the three digits must be 0. (Rudimentary)  
5. Use the given total sum 11 to infer that the other two digits must sum to 11. (Rudimentary)  
6. Apply the “one digit is exactly one greater than another” condition to pairs summing to 11; the only valid single-digit pair is 5 and 6 (1 and 10 is impossible). (Rudimentary)  
7. Combine results to state the three digits are 0, 5, and 6. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Interpret Eric’s statement: he could only “know the numbers” from the product if that product is produced by exactly one valid triple; therefore, for Luke to be sure Eric lied, the digit Luke sees must make such uniqueness impossible. (Creative)  
2. Check each digit 1–9 and show that for each one there exists at least one triple whose product is unique (e.g., 8,8,8 → 512; 6,7,7 → 294; 2,7,7 → 98; 4,5,5 → 100; 3,9,9 → 243; 1,1,1 → 1). Hence, seeing any of these digits would not let Luke conclude Eric lied. (Rudimentary)  
3. Observe that if Luke sees a 0, every triple containing 0 has product 0, so product = 0 can never single out one triple; thus Eric could not have been certain, and Luke would instantly know Eric lied. (Creative)  
4. Deduce that one of the three digits must be 0. (Rudimentary)  
5. Use the given total sum 11 to infer that the other two digits must sum to 11. (Rudimentary)  
6. Apply the “one digit is exactly one greater than another” condition to pairs summing to 11; the only valid single-digit pair is 5 and 6 (1 and 10 is impossible). (Rudimentary)  
7. Combine results to state the three digits are 0, 5, and 6. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
What would be the missing letter ?
O Q L H R
I J F E Q
--------------
F G F C ?
Human Solution:
The missing letter is A.
Number the letters in order eg: A=1 B=2 C=3 etc.. then subtract the middle from the top, to give the bottom number. Assign that number to the appropriate letter to give the answer.
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Notice/decide that a workable pattern could arise by translating each letter to its alphabetical position and performing arithmetic on those numbers (specifically, subtraction of the middle-row value from the top-row value in each column).  
2. Rudimentary – Convert every letter in the top and middle rows to its numeric place in the alphabet (A = 1, B = 2, …, Z = 26).  
3. Rudimentary – For each of the first four columns, subtract the middle-row number from the corresponding top-row number, then translate the numerical result back to a letter. Verify that these results match the given bottom-row letters (F, G, F, C), confirming the discovered rule.  
4. Rudimentary – Apply the same subtraction to the last column: R (18) – Q (17) = 1, translate 1 back to a letter → A. Therefore, the missing letter is A.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 4  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. Creative – Notice/decide that a workable pattern could arise by translating each letter to its alphabetical position and performing arithmetic on those numbers (specifically, subtraction of the middle-row value from the top-row value in each column).  
2. Rudimentary – Convert every letter in the top and middle rows to its numeric place in the alphabet (A = 1, B = 2, …, Z = 26).  
3. Rudimentary – For each of the first four columns, subtract the middle-row number from the corresponding top-row number, then translate the numerical result back to a letter. Verify that these results match the given bottom-row letters (F, G, F, C), confirming the discovered rule.  
4. Rudimentary – Apply the same subtraction to the last column: R (18) – Q (17) = 1, translate 1 back to a letter → A. Therefore, the missing letter is A.']

Question:
It is a sunny and warm spring day in Cipher, South Decoder. Fans at the baseball park have come to see their own Cipher Solvers play their rivals, the Rockford Peaches, in the first game of the season. Everyone is hoping for a good show.
The home fans became very vocal as 5 of their players (Tim, Hank, K.C., Flynn, and Jimmy Blake) either made an exciting play to allow runs to score, or made an embarrassing error - or both!
Scorecard
Names: Tim, Hank, K.C., Flynn, Jimmy Blake
Positions: pitcher, catcher, 3rd base, shortstop, left field
RBIs: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
Errors: 0, 1, ?, 2, 3
First Inning
By the end of the game, two players were charged with the same number of errors, either 1 or 2. This number (?) is to be deduced from the clues.
Second Inning
No player ended up with the same number of errors and RBIs.
Third Inning
The left fielder had his 1 RBI when, with runners at 1st and 3rd, he hit one over the head of the Peaches' 2nd baseman and into right field.
Fourth Inning
Jimmy Blake earned his 2 RBIs when he hit a triple, allowing the center fielder and the 3rd baseman to score.
Fifth Inning
Flynn had his 1 error when he missed a throw to 1st base.
Sixth Inning
Tim, who posted either 2 or 3 RBIs, ended up with 1 error more than the pitcher after he (Tim) quite literally dropped the ball.
Seventh Inning
The player who finished with no RBIs and 2 errors, including fumbling a fly ball, doesn't play 3rd base.
Eighth Inning
The player who had his 3 RBIs with a game-tying in-the-park home run that had the fans on their feet, scored at least 1 error, but he had fewer errors than the shortstop.
Ninth Inning
K.C. ended the game with 2 fewer errors than the catcher, who let a wild pitch get past him so that the Peaches regained the lead.
Can you determine which position the boys played, as well as how many runs batted in (RBI) and errors they made?
Human Solution:
Hank (catcher) with 0 RBIs and 2 errors
K.C. (left field) with 1 RBI and 0 errors
Jimmy Blake (shortstop) with 2 RBIs and 3 errors
Tim (3rd base) with 3 RBIs and 2 errors
Flynn (pitcher) with 4 RBIs and 1 error
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Conclude that Hank is the catcher and finished the game with 0 RBIs and 2 errors.  
2. Conclude that K.C. is the left fielder and finished the game with 1 RBI and 0 errors.  
3. Conclude that Jimmy Blake is the shortstop and finished the game with 2 RBIs and 3 errors.  
4. Conclude that Tim is the 3rd baseman and finished the game with 3 RBIs and 2 errors.  
5. Conclude that Flynn is the pitcher and finished the game with 4 RBIs and 1 error.

['Total Step Count: 5  
Creative ', ' 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Conclude that Hank is the catcher and finished the game with 0 RBIs and 2 errors.  
2. Conclude that K.C. is the left fielder and finished the game with 1 RBI and 0 errors.  
3. Conclude that Jimmy Blake is the shortstop and finished the game with 2 RBIs and 3 errors.  
4. Conclude that Tim is the 3rd baseman and finished the game with 3 RBIs and 2 errors.  
5. Conclude that Flynn is the pitcher and finished the game with 4 RBIs and 1 error.']

Question:
There were 9 portraits of animals (bear, cat, dog, hamster, horse, lion, monkey, mouse, and tiger) on a wall of a museum.  As I was studying them, I tripped and fell into the wall and they all fell down. I have to get them back up on the wall in the correct order before I get into some serious trouble.  I only remember a couple of things about the order of the portraits.  Can you help me figure out the order of the portraits using the clues I remember about them?
They were displayed as follows:
Note: The Letter and Numbers in the graph are labels for their corresponding rows.
...........A...............B.............C
1    _________ l _________ l _________
2    _________ l _________ l _________
3    _________ l _________ l _________
Clues:
1.  The bear is in the same row as the hamster.
2.  Two portraits in both rows 3 and C have two animals that start with the same letter.
3.  The horse is in the same row as the monkey.
4.  The dog is in 2A.
5.  Either the lion or the tiger is below the cat.
6.  The monkey is either above or below the dog.
7.  The dog is not next to the tiger.
Human Solution:
bear      l cat        l hamster
dog       l lion       l tiger
monkey l mouse  l horse
Response:
Total Step Count: 9  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Apply clue 4 and place the Dog in position 2A.  
2. (Rudimentary)  Combine clues 6 and 3 to note that the Monkey must be directly above or below the Dog (1A or 3A) and that the Horse must share the Monkey’s row.  
3. (Creative)  Use clue 2 (“two portraits in row 3 share an initial”) together with the list of animals to pick the only feasible same-letter pair that can also include the Monkey: Monkey/Mouse.  Decide therefore that row 3 will contain Monkey, Mouse, and Horse (satisfying clue 3 as well).  
4. (Rudimentary)  Fix their exact locations in row 3 so that the Monkey is under the Dog (3A), the Mouse goes in the remaining middle spot (3B), and the Horse takes 3C.  
5. (Creative)  Column C now holds Horse (3C); to satisfy the “two same-letter portraits in column C” part of clue 2, place the Hamster in 1C so that column C has two H’s (Hamster and Horse).  
6. (Rudimentary)  By clue 1, the Bear must share a row with the Hamster, so Bear is either 1A or 1B.  
7. (Rudimentary)  Use clue 5 (Lion or Tiger must be below the Cat) and reserve column B for that relation by tentatively putting the Cat in 1B, leaving 2B for Lion or Tiger.  
8. (Creative)  Satisfy both clue 7 (Dog not next to Tiger) and clue 5 by placing Lion in 2B (directly under the Cat) and Tiger in 2C, which is not adjacent to the Dog in 2A.  Column C still keeps its pair of H’s.  
9. (Rudimentary)  The only remaining empty slot is 1A, so place the Bear there, completing the wall as:  
   • Row 1: Bear  Cat  Hamster  
   • Row 2: Dog  Lion  Tiger  
   • Row 3: Monkey  Mouse  Horse

['Total Step Count: 9  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 6  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Apply clue 4 and place the Dog in position 2A.  
2. (Rudimentary)  Combine clues 6 and 3 to note that the Monkey must be directly above or below the Dog (1A or 3A) and that the Horse must share the Monkey’s row.  
3. (Creative)  Use clue 2 (“two portraits in row 3 share an initial”) together with the list of animals to pick the only feasible same-letter pair that can also include the Monkey: Monkey/Mouse.  Decide therefore that row 3 will contain Monkey, Mouse, and Horse (satisfying clue 3 as well).  
4. (Rudimentary)  Fix their exact locations in row 3 so that the Monkey is under the Dog (3A), the Mouse goes in the remaining middle spot (3B), and the Horse takes 3C.  
5. (Creative)  Column C now holds Horse (3C); to satisfy the “two same-letter portraits in column C” part of clue 2, place the Hamster in 1C so that column C has two H’s (Hamster and Horse).  
6. (Rudimentary)  By clue 1, the Bear must share a row with the Hamster, so Bear is either 1A or 1B.  
7. (Rudimentary)  Use clue 5 (Lion or Tiger must be below the Cat) and reserve column B for that relation by tentatively putting the Cat in 1B, leaving 2B for Lion or Tiger.

9. (Rudimentary)  The only remaining empty slot is 1A, so place the Bear there, completing the wall as:  
   • Row 1: Bear  Cat  Hamster  
   • Row 2: Dog  Lion  Tiger  
   • Row 3: Monkey  Mouse  Horse']

Question:
John, Paul, George, and Ringo were playing a card game. Each player had three cards, one of the four suits was the "high suit." When each player played one card, this was a "trick." The first card played in a trick was the "leading suit." Here are the cards in each man's hand:
John: club, heart, diamond
Paul: club, spade, spade
George: club, heart, heart
Ringo: spade, diamond, diamond
If possible, each player had to play the leading suit for each trick. If they couldn't do that, they had to play the high suit. And if they couldn't do that, they could play any card. A player who won a trick had to lead the next trick. Each of the three tricks consisted of the leading card, exactly one other card of the same suit, exactly one card of the high suit which won its player the trick, and exactly one other card. Which suit was the high suit?
Hint:
This makes the puzzle too easy. Please stop reading if you don't want it to be too easy.
Lucy in the sky with...
Human Solution:
The high suit is diamonds.
The first trick obviously required two cards of the leading suit, and since everyone had to play the leading suit if possible, there had to be two people who had at least one card of the first leading suit. But since John, Paul, and George each had a club, the first leading suit could not have been a club.
If the first leading suit was a heart, then the high suit had to be a card of which only one of Paul and Ringo had. This means it could only have been a club or a diamond. Similarly, if the first leading suit was a spade, the high suit could only have been a diamond, and if the leading suit was a diamond, the high suit could only have been a heart or a spade.
If the first leading suit was a heart, the second trick was led by either Paul or Ringo, and the leading suit had to be a spade. If the first leading suit was a spade, the second trick was led by John, and the leading suit could have been a club or a heart. If the first leading suit was a diamond, the second trick was led by either Paul or George, and the leading suit was a club. Now we can deduce the six possible leading suits and high suits for the whole game:
1. heart, heart, club
spade, spade, club
diamond, diamond, club
2. heart, heart, diamond
spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
3. spade, spade, diamond
club, club, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
4. spade, spade, diamond
heart, heart, diamond
club, club, diamond
5. diamond, diamond, heart
club, club, heart
spade, spade, heart
6. diamond, diamond, spade
club, club, spade
heart, heart, spade
Game 1 cannot be possible because Paul would have led the spade and John and George would both have played a club, making two cards of the high suit. Games 5 and 6 cannot be possible because no one had both hearts and spades. This leaves only games 2, 3, and 4, which all have diamonds as the high suit.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Observe that every trick must contain exactly two cards of the leading suit. Since three players (John, Paul, George) all hold a club, the first leading suit cannot be clubs—otherwise three cards of the leading suit would appear.  

2. (Creative) Consider each remaining possibility for the first leading suit (hearts, spades, diamonds) and, using the “follow-suit/else high-suit” rule, deduce which suits could serve as the single high-suit card in that first trick:  
   • Leading hearts ⇒ high suit could be clubs or diamonds (only Paul or Ringo could supply it).  
   • Leading spades ⇒ high suit must be diamonds.  
   • Leading diamonds ⇒ high suit could be hearts or spades.  

3. (Creative) For each of those first-trick scenarios, identify who would win the trick (the sole high-suit player) and therefore who would lead the second trick; then infer what the second leading suit could be under the same two-of-the-suit rule.  

4. (Rudimentary) Combine the deductions from Steps 2–3 to list every complete three-trick sequence of leading suits together with its single high suit, producing six candidate “games.”  

5. (Rudimentary) Check Game 1 and discard it because Paul’s spade lead would force both John and George to play clubs, giving two high-suit cards instead of one.  

6. (Rudimentary) Discard Games 5 and 6 because they require some player to possess both hearts and spades, which no one does.  

7. (Rudimentary) Note that the only remaining viable Games 2, 3, and 4 all use diamonds as the high suit; therefore conclude that diamonds is the high suit.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Observe that every trick must contain exactly two cards of the leading suit. Since three players (John, Paul, George) all hold a club, the first leading suit cannot be clubs—otherwise three cards of the leading suit would appear.  

2. (Creative) Consider each remaining possibility for the first leading suit (hearts, spades, diamonds) and, using the “follow-suit/else high-suit” rule, deduce which suits could serve as the single high-suit card in that first trick:  
   • Leading hearts ⇒ high suit could be clubs or diamonds (only Paul or Ringo could supply it).  
   • Leading spades ⇒ high suit must be diamonds.  
   • Leading diamonds ⇒ high suit could be hearts or spades.  

3. (Creative) For each of those first-trick scenarios, identify who would win the trick (the sole high-suit player) and therefore who would lead the second trick; then infer what the second leading suit could be under the same two-of-the-suit rule.  

4. (Rudimentary) Combine the deductions from Steps 2–3 to list every complete three-trick sequence of leading suits together with its single high suit, producing six candidate “games.”  

5. (Rudimentary) Check Game 1 and discard it because Paul’s spade lead would force both John and George to play clubs, giving two high-suit cards instead of one.  

6. (Rudimentary) Discard Games 5 and 6 because they require some player to possess both hearts and spades, which no one does.  

7. (Rudimentary) Note that the only remaining viable Games 2, 3, and 4 all use diamonds as the high suit; therefore conclude that diamonds is the high suit.']

Question: There are 10 people who could be the owner of the bank. They all sit in separate chairs across a long table facing north. The table is made of aluminium. The owner of the bank sits next to M. M sits on the left side of the banker. M sits next to C. C sits 4 places to the left of L. L sits next to O and rarely talks to S, E or Z, because they hate him and because they sit on the far right of the bank. O does not sit next to the owner of the bank. The two people left are F and T. T hates the owner of the bank and is considering resigning. Give the names of all the bankers from left to right.
Hint: Think from the banker's point of view and draw a diagram.
Human Solution: TCMBFLOSEZ.
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Set up a working diagram: ten consecutively-numbered seats in a single row, left-to-right, because everyone is “facing north.”  

2. (Creative)  Interpret the sentence “…S, E or Z … sit on the far right of the bank” as meaning that the three seats furthest to the right (seats 8, 9, 10) must be occupied, in some order, by S, E and Z.  

3. (Rudimentary)  Conclude that L cannot be in seats 8, 9 or 10, and place L immediately to the left of that right-hand block so that he “rarely talks” to them; the only seat that satisfies this is seat 6 (leaving one buffer seat between L and the right-hand trio).  

4. (Rudimentary)  Apply “C sits four places to the left of L,” giving C → seat 2 (since seat 6 – 4 = 2).  

5. (Rudimentary)  Record the partial layout:  
   seat 2 = C, seat 6 = L, seats 8-10 = {S,E,Z}.  

6. (Creative)  Translate “The owner of the bank sits next to M, and M sits on the left side of the banker” into the ordered pair (M, B) occupying two adjacent seats with M on the immediate left of B.  

7. (Rudimentary)  Eliminate any (M,B) placements that would put B next to O (because “O does not sit next to the owner”) or would overlap filled seats. The only viable spot is seats 3 and 4, giving seat 3 = M and seat 4 = B.  

8. (Rudimentary)  Satisfy “L sits next to O” by placing O in one of the seats adjacent to L; seat 7 would place O adjacent to the S/E/Z block (heightening interaction), so choose seat 5 for O.  

9. (Rudimentary)  The remaining unfilled seats are seat 1 and seat 7, and the remaining names are F and T. Use “T hates the owner of the bank” to avoid putting T immediately next to B (seat 4). Neither seat 1 nor seat 7 is adjacent to seat 4, so either works; adopt the ordering that completes the given solution by assigning seat 1 = T and seat 7 = F.  

10. (Rudimentary)  List the occupants from left to right to obtain the final arrangement:  
    T C M B F L O S E Z.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 10  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. (Rudimentary)  Set up a working diagram: ten consecutively-numbered seats in a single row, left-to-right, because everyone is “facing north.”  

2. (Creative)  Interpret the sentence “…S, E or Z … sit on the far right of the bank” as meaning that the three seats furthest to the right (seats 8, 9, 10) must be occupied, in some order, by S, E and Z.  

3. (Rudimentary)  Conclude that L cannot be in seats 8, 9 or 10, and place L immediately to the left of that right-hand block so that he “rarely talks” to them; the only seat that satisfies this is seat 6 (leaving one buffer seat between L and the right-hand trio).  

4. (Rudimentary)  Apply “C sits four places to the left of L,” giving C → seat 2 (since seat 6 – 4 = 2).  

5. (Rudimentary)  Record the partial layout:  
   seat 2 = C, seat 6 = L, seats 8-10 = {S,E,Z}.  

6. (Creative)  Translate “The owner of the bank sits next to M, and M sits on the left side of the banker” into the ordered pair (M, B) occupying two adjacent seats with M on the immediate left of B.  

7. (Rudimentary)  Eliminate any (M,B) placements that would put B next to O (because “O does not sit next to the owner”) or would overlap filled seats. The only viable spot is seats 3 and 4, giving seat 3 = M and seat 4 = B.  

8. (Rudimentary)  Satisfy “L sits next to O” by placing O in one of the seats adjacent to L; seat 7 would place O adjacent to the S/E/Z block (heightening interaction), so choose seat 5 for O.  

9. (Rudimentary)  The remaining unfilled seats are seat 1 and seat 7, and the remaining names are F and T. Use “T hates the owner of the bank” to avoid putting T immediately next to B (seat 4). Neither seat 1 nor seat 7 is adjacent to seat 4, so either works; adopt the ordering that completes the given solution by assigning seat 1 = T and seat 7 = F.

    T C M B F L O S E Z.']

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
- stands for E, O, L, C, or W
= stands for J, K, U, R, or S
* stands for B, O, P, F, or C
+ stands for D, G, I, M, or A
/ stands for F, N, H, E, or R
The five letter code word, */+-=, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Human Solution: Order and Chaos.
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. List the five possible letters that each of the five symbols (*, /, +, -, =) can represent, establishing the pool of candidates for every position in the code word. (Rudimentary)

2. Note that the problem asks for two English words that are opposites and that both must be obtainable from the same symbolic pattern */+-=. Therefore, search for 5-letter antonym pairs that could conceivably be spelled with the available letter pools. (Rudimentary)

3. Test candidate antonym pairs against the letter pools until finding a pair that satisfies all constraints; the pair ORDER and CHAOS is discovered. (Creative)

4. Confirm that both words can indeed be formed by choosing allowable letters for each symbol:  
   • ORDER → * = O, / = R, + = D, – = E, = = R  
   • CHAOS → * = C, / = H, + = A, – = O, = = S  
   Since every chosen letter is in its respective symbol’s pool, the solution is valid. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 4  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 3  

Steps:  
1. List the five possible letters that each of the five symbols (*, /, +, -, =) can represent, establishing the pool of candidates for every position in the code word. (Rudimentary)

2. Note that the problem asks for two English words that are opposites and that both must be obtainable from the same symbolic pattern */+-=. Therefore, search for 5-letter antonym pairs that could conceivably be spelled with the available letter pools. (Rudimentary)

3. Test candidate antonym pairs against the letter pools until finding a pair that satisfies all constraints; the pair ORDER and CHAOS is discovered. (Creative)

4. Confirm that both words can indeed be formed by choosing allowable letters for each symbol:  
   • ORDER → * = O, / = R, + = D, – = E, = = R  
   • CHAOS → * = C, / = H, + = A, – = O, = = S  
   Since every chosen letter is in its respective symbol’s pool, the solution is valid. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
* stands for L, T, K, C, or N
) stands for D, O, E, H, or S
+ stands for N, G, I, O, or X
( stands for Y, T, E, P, or F
_ stands for R, B, M, A, or S
The five letter code word, (+_*), can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
Hint: In music...

Question:
A bridge was guarded by an evil troll. The troll was very intelligent, but he was also a coward. He was afraid of anyone smarter than him. So every time anyone tried to cross the bridge, the troll would set up a test. If the traveler passed the test, he would be allowed to cross. Otherwise, the troll would eat him.
Three travelers, Al, Ben and Carl, came across the bridge. The troll told them, "You may only cross my bridge if you know the password." He wrote five three-letter words on a rock. The five words were HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, and VAT.
He then said, "I will tell each of you a different letter from the password. If you know what the password is, I will let you pass. But don't tell anyone else your letter." He then whispered a letter from the password to each traveler so that neither of the other two could hear him.
Then the troll asked Al, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Al, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Ben, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Ben, and the troll let him pass.
Then the troll asked Carl, "Do you know what the password is?" "Yes," said Carl, and the troll let him pass.
So, what is the password?
Hint:
1. Ben used Al's answer, and Carl used both Al's and Ben's answers.
2. Al's letter could not have been E.
Human Solution:
The password was HOE.
The only letters unique to one of the five words were D, H, P, R, and V. One of these letters must have been Al's, since he could determine the password. The only word without any of these letters is TOE. So the password could not have been TOE.
Ben knew this and now had four words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, P, R, T, and V. The password must have contained at least two unique letters, one for Al and the other for Ben, since they were both able to determine the password. The only word with only one of these letters was OAR. So OAR could not have been the password.
Carl knew this and now had three words to think of. The only letters unique to one word were D, E, H, O, P, T, and V. The password must have included three of these letters, since all three were able to determine the password. The only one of the three words containing three such letters was HOE, so this must have been the password.
Response:
Total Step Count: 8  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. List the five candidate words supplied by the troll: HOE, OAR, PAD, TOE, VAT. (Rudimentary)

2. For the full list of five words, identify letters that occur in exactly one word; these are D, H, P, R, and V. (Rudimentary)

3. Reason that Al could name the password after hearing a single letter; this can happen only if his letter is one of the unique letters from Step 2. Therefore the password must contain at least one of D, H, P, R, V, eliminating any word lacking all of them—so TOE cannot be the password. (Creative)

4. With TOE removed, recompute the letters that are now unique among the remaining four words (HOE, OAR, PAD, VAT). The unique-letter set is now D, E, H, P, R, T, V. (Rudimentary)

5. Observe that Ben also identified the password from a single letter; hence the password must contain two different unique letters (one for Al, one for Ben). Among the four words, OAR has only one such unique letter, so OAR is ruled out. (Creative)

6. The surviving candidates are HOE, PAD, and VAT. Determine which letters are unique within this trio; they are D, E, H, O, P, T, V. (Rudimentary)

7. Since Carl likewise knew the password from one letter, the password must now contain three distinct unique letters (one for each traveler). HOE is the only remaining word containing three of the currently unique letters, so it must be the password. (Creative)

8. State the final answer: the password is HOE. (Rudimentary)

Question:
The following statements were made by each of eight people at a family reunion. They are each referring to one of the other seven people (in other words the person being referred to in the first statement, Maria, is making one of the other statements). Can you determine who made each statement? Assume that all parents are married and that all married couples are heterosexual, married only once, still married, and attending together.
1.  "I am Maria's niece."
2.  "Christopher is my only cousin."
3.  "Clarissa is my brother's wife."
4.  "I am Donna's sister."
5.  "Jonathan is my uncle."
6.  "Theodore is my brother."
7.  "Ben is my nephew."
8.  "Judy is my daughter."
Human Solution:
1.  Donna
2.  Ben
3.  Theodore
4.  Judy
5.  Christopher
6.  Jonathan
7.  Maria
8.  Clarissa
I had trouble coming up with a nice, straightforward logical solution for this problem so I had to use a little trial and error.  Since no grandchildren are mentioned, I assumed that there were only two generations present.  I started with the women:  I used statements 1 and 3 to put Maria and Clarissa in the older generation, respectively.  Then I used statements 4 and 8 to put Donna and Judy in the younger generation, as sisters.  Statement 7 puts Ben in the younger generation.  If Christopher is also in the younger generation, then Ben must be Donna and Judy's brother and either Ben or Donna says statement 2.  If Theodore and Jonathan are in the older generation, then Jonathan must be Clarissa's husband and Theodore must be Jonathan's brother (Statement 3).  Statement 1 has to be said by Donna, since she is the only girl left in the younger generation who could say that.  This leaves Ben saying statement 2.  By elimination, Clarissa must give statement 8 and Maria statement 7.  The only thing left is for Christopher to make statement 5.
Response:
Total Step Count: 10  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 8  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Notice that no statement mentions grandchildren, so assume only two generations are present; this greatly reduces the possible relationships that have to be considered.  

2. (Rudimentary) Use statements 1 (“I am Maria’s niece”) and 3 (“Clarissa is my brother’s wife”) to place Maria and Clarissa in the older generation.  

3. (Rudimentary) Use statements 4 (“I am Donna’s sister”) and 8 (“Judy is my daughter”) to place Donna and Judy in the younger generation and to establish that the two are sisters.  

4. (Rudimentary) Use statement 7 (“Ben is my nephew”) to place Ben in the younger generation.  

5. (Creative) Choose the working assumption that Christopher is also in the younger generation; from this, infer that Ben must be Donna and Judy’s brother, so statement 2 (“Christopher is my only cousin”) must be said by either Ben or Donna.  

6. (Rudimentary) Put Theodore and Jonathan in the older generation; then, by statement 3, Jonathan must be Clarissa’s husband and Theodore must be Jonathan’s brother.  

7. (Rudimentary) Determine that statement 1 (“I am Maria’s niece”) must be said by Donna, because she is the only remaining female in the younger generation able to make it.  

8. (Rudimentary) Conclude that Ben therefore makes statement 2 (“Christopher is my only cousin”).  

9. (Rudimentary) By elimination, assign statement 8 (“Judy is my daughter”) to Clarissa and statement 7 (“Ben is my nephew”) to Maria.  

10. (Rudimentary) The one unassigned statement is 5 (“Jonathan is my uncle”), so it must be made by Christopher.

runway : cinema
answer : ?
Directions: Ratios usually involve numbers.  This word ratio is a little different in that all four words in the ratio are somehow related.  Can you find a word that completes the ratio?
(Note: there is more than one possible answer.)
Human Solution:
Any 6-letter word with the letters "se" in the middle will complete the word ratio. Possible answers include the words absent, assert, bisect, desert, insect, itself, losers, misery, museum, resent, unseen, wisely, etc.
The middle two letters of each of the words in the ratio represents a direction. The embedded directions relate to the position of the word within the ratio.
ruNWay: ciNEma
anSWer: abSEnt

Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 2

2. Infer that the word ratio is organized around the four diagonal compass directions (NW, NE, SW, SE), so the third word should hide “SW” and the missing fourth word should hide “SE.” – Creative  

3. Confirm that the third word already supplied in the ratio, “answer,” indeed contains “SW” in its center, fitting the inferred pattern. – Rudimentary  

4. Conclude that any six-letter word whose middle two letters are “SE” will satisfy the ratio, and list possible examples such as “absent,” “assert,” “bisect,” “desert,” “insect,” “itself,” “losers,” “misery,” “museum,” “resent,” “unseen,” and “wisely.” – Rudimentary

Question:
Mad Ade sat at home, waiting for his favourite TV program "I'm a celebrity, Get me a Kebab" to start. He glanced at his clock and began to wonder strange and wondrous things, but that is another story altogether.
He realised that he could leave 6 adjacent numbers of the face of a clock intact and rearrange the other 6 in such a way that the sum of every pair of adjacent numbers is prime.
Unfortunately the TV program started at that point so he never actually got around to doing it. Can you find the two possible solutions to Mad Ade's clock teaser?
Human Solution:
Imagining the number on a clock face in a clockwise order they would be
1 2 3 4 7 10 9 8 5 6 11 12
Or
1 2 3 4 9 10 7 6 5 8 11 12
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. Choose the block of six consecutive positions that will be left unchanged; select the arc 11-12-1-2-3-4, thus fixing the numbers 11, 12, 1, 2, 3, 4 in place.  
2. Work out one ordering of the six movable numbers (5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10) – namely 7, 10, 9, 8, 5, 6 – that makes every pair of adjacent numbers around the dial sum to a prime.  
3. Write down the complete clockwise order for this first valid clock:  
   1  2  3  4  7  10  9  8  5  6  11  12.  
4. Discover the only other ordering of the movable numbers that satisfies the same prime-sum condition, namely 9, 10, 7, 6, 5, 8.  
5. Record the complete clockwise order for this second valid clock:  
   1  2  3  4  9  10  7  6  5  8  11  12.

2. Work out one ordering of the six movable numbers (5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10) – namely 7, 10, 9, 8, 5, 6 – that makes every pair of adjacent numbers around the dial sum to a prime.  
3. Write down the complete clockwise order for this first valid clock:  
   1  2  3  4  7  10  9  8  5  6  11  12.  
4. Discover the only other ordering of the movable numbers that satisfies the same prime-sum condition, namely 9, 10, 7, 6, 5, 8.  
5. Record the complete clockwise order for this second valid clock:  
   1  2  3  4  9  10  7  6  5  8  11  12.']

Question: Adam, Ben and Cyril were born in 1309, 1310 and 1311 on the same road in old Jerusalem. They lived their whole life there, and all lived to be over 60. They also had a full active life. However, they never crossed paths with each other. Why should that be so?
Human Solution: Adam was a Muslim, Ben was a Christian and Cyril was a Jew. Adam was born in 1309 of the Muslim calendar, Ben 1310 in the Christian calendar and Cyril 1311 in the Jewish calendar. Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben, who in turn was born 619 years before Adam.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Observe the apparent paradox: three people born in “1309, 1310, 1311,” lived on the same road, reached old age, yet never met. (Rudimentary)  

2. Realize that the years 1309-1311 might belong to different calendar systems rather than to the same era. (Creative)  

3. Recall that in Jerusalem three major religious communities use distinct calendars—the Muslim (Hijri), Christian (Gregorian/Julian), and Jewish (Hebrew) calendars. (Creative)  

4. Match each person with the calendar used by his faith: Adam → 1309 AH, Ben → 1310 AD, Cyril → 1311 AM (Anno Mundi, Jewish calendar). (Creative)  

5. Convert those calendar dates to a common (Gregorian) timeline:  
   • 1311 AM ≈ 2450 BCE  
   • 1310 AD = 1310 CE  
   • 1309 AH ≈ 1891 CE. (Rudimentary)  

6. Compute the separations: Cyril was born over 3000 years before Ben; Ben was born 619 years before Adam. (Rudimentary)  

7. Conclude that, although they all lived on the same road, the vast differences in their actual birth centuries prevented their lives from overlapping, so they never crossed paths. (Rudimentary)

Rudimentary Steps: 4

3. Recall that in Jerusalem three major religious communities use distinct calendars—the Muslim (Hijri), Christian (Gregorian/Julian), and Jewish (Hebrew) calendars. (Creative)

5. Convert those calendar dates to a common (Gregorian) timeline:  
   • 1311 AM ≈ 2450 BCE  
   • 1310 AD = 1310 CE  
   • 1309 AH ≈ 1891 CE. (Rudimentary)

Question: You and your spouse invite four other couples to a party. During the course of the conversation, it is discovered that, prior to the party, each person except you was acquainted with a different number of the people present. Assuming the acquaintance relationship is symmetric (i.e., if you are acquainted with someone, that person is also acquainted with you), then how many people did your spouse know prior to the party? How many people did you know?
Human Solution:
Start with the assumption that everybody knows their own spouses -- which means that everybody there knew at least one person. Discounting yourself, everyone knows a different number of people, which means that (again, discounting yourself) one person knows one, one person knows two, one person knows three, etc., up to one person who knows nine people (everybody else). Number the people (besides yourself) according to how many people they know, so that person 1 is the one who knows one person, person 2 is the one who knows two people, etc.
Now pair up people with their spouses. If person 9 knows everybody else, s/he must be the only person who knows person 1, because person 1 only knows one person. So they must be married. Person 8 knows everybody except for person 1. Person 2 therefore knows person 8 and person 9. Person 9 is married to person 1, so person 2's spouse must be person 8. Person 7 knows everybody except for persons 1 and 2. Person 3 therefore knows persons 7, 8, and 9. Persons 8 and 9 are married to persons 2 and 1 respectively, so person 3's spouse must be person 7. Person 6 knows everybody except for persons 1, 2, and 3. Person 4 therefore knows persons 6, 7, 8, and 9. The only one of those not yet paired up is person 6, so person 4 and person 6 must be married.
This leaves person 5, who knows everyone except persons 1, 2, 3, and 4. These five people, therefore, must be persons 6, 7, 8, 9, and you. Since you are the only one of these five not yet paired up, person 5 must be your spouse. So your spouse knew five people prior to the party.
The above also determines that the people who know you are persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. So you knew five people prior to the party also.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Realize that, aside from you, the nine other guests each know a distinct number of people ranging from 1 to 9 (inclusive) because (i) everyone knows at least his or her own spouse and (ii) the problem states all acquaintance counts are different.  Label the nine guests “Person 1” through “Person 9,” where Person k knows exactly k people.  (Creative)

2. Use symmetry of acquaintance to see that Person 1’s single acquaintance must be the only guest who knows everybody—Person 9—so Persons 1 and 9 must be married.  (Creative)

3. Knowing that Person 9 is married to Person 1, note that Person 8 knows everyone except Person 1.  The only guest who can now fulfil the description “knows exactly two people” is Person 2, who must know Persons 8 and 9; therefore Persons 2 and 8 are spouses.  (Rudimentary)

4. Extend the same reasoning: Person 7 knows everyone except Persons 1 and 2, so the guest who knows exactly three people (Persons 7, 8, 9) is Person 3.  Hence Persons 3 and 7 form another couple.  (Rudimentary)

5. Continue once more: Person 6 knows everyone except Persons 1, 2, 3, leaving Person 4 (who knows 6, 7, 8, 9) as the one with exactly four acquaintances; thus Persons 4 and 6 are married.  (Rudimentary)

6. The only unpaired numbered guest is Person 5.  Since you are also still unpaired, Person 5 must be your spouse.  Consequently, your spouse knew five people before the party.  (Rudimentary)

7. From the pairings, the people who knew you beforehand are Persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9, so you likewise knew five people before the party.  (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 7  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Realize that, aside from you, the nine other guests each know a distinct number of people ranging from 1 to 9 (inclusive) because (i) everyone knows at least his or her own spouse and (ii) the problem states all acquaintance counts are different.  Label the nine guests “Person 1” through “Person 9,” where Person k knows exactly k people.  (Creative)

2. Use symmetry of acquaintance to see that Person 1’s single acquaintance must be the only guest who knows everybody—Person 9—so Persons 1 and 9 must be married.  (Creative)

3. Knowing that Person 9 is married to Person 1, note that Person 8 knows everyone except Person 1.  The only guest who can now fulfil the description “knows exactly two people” is Person 2, who must know Persons 8 and 9; therefore Persons 2 and 8 are spouses.  (Rudimentary)

4. Extend the same reasoning: Person 7 knows everyone except Persons 1 and 2, so the guest who knows exactly three people (Persons 7, 8, 9) is Person 3.  Hence Persons 3 and 7 form another couple.  (Rudimentary)

5. Continue once more: Person 6 knows everyone except Persons 1, 2, 3, leaving Person 4 (who knows 6, 7, 8, 9) as the one with exactly four acquaintances; thus Persons 4 and 6 are married.  (Rudimentary)

6. The only unpaired numbered guest is Person 5.  Since you are also still unpaired, Person 5 must be your spouse.  Consequently, your spouse knew five people before the party.  (Rudimentary)

7. From the pairings, the people who knew you beforehand are Persons 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9, so you likewise knew five people before the party.  (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Nick has always wanted one, so he goes out and buys a brand new one for £5000.  Unfortunately the next day he breaks it, so he goes out again and gets another brand new one. This time however, it only costs him £25. The next day someone offers to buy it off of him for £6000.
What is it ?
Human Solution: A personalised number plate.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. List all of the problem’s key facts: an item can be bought “brand-new” for £5 000, physically broken the next day, re-purchased “brand-new” for only £25, and later someone is willing to pay £6 000 for it. (Rudimentary)

2. Notice that the huge drop from £5 000 to £25 implies that what is really valuable is not the physical object itself but some underlying right or ownership that remains intact even if the physical object is damaged. (Creative)

3. Brainstorm objects whose legal right or registration is expensive while the physical replacement is cheap — e.g., deeds, licenses, certificates, personalised number plates, etc. (Creative)

4. Test which candidate satisfies every clue and recognise that a personalised car registration does: the registration (the right to the number) costs thousands, a replacement pair of acrylic plates costs about £25 after the original ones are “broken,” and desirable registrations can be sold on for even more (here £6 000). (Creative)

5. Conclude that the mysterious item is a personalised number plate. (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 5  
Creative ', ' 3  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. List all of the problem’s key facts: an item can be bought “brand-new” for £5 000, physically broken the next day, re-purchased “brand-new” for only £25, and later someone is willing to pay £6 000 for it. (Rudimentary)

3. Brainstorm objects whose legal right or registration is expensive while the physical replacement is cheap — e.g., deeds, licenses, certificates, personalised number plates, etc. (Creative)

4. Test which candidate satisfies every clue and recognise that a personalised car registration does: the registration (the right to the number) costs thousands, a replacement pair of acrylic plates costs about £25 after the original ones are “broken,” and desirable registrations can be sold on for even more (here £6 000). (Creative)

Question:
Four friends named Jane, June, Jean and Jenny discovered that, if a different non-zero integer was assigned to each letter of their names and added together, it produced their ages.
June is 17, Jenny is two years older, while Jane and Jean are both sweet 16.  All the girls agree that June is in her prime.  Can you find the numbers the girls assigned to each letter of their names?
(There are two possible answers.)
Hint: prime...
Human Solution:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3; A=6; Y=4
or
J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2; A=6; Y=4
The little clue 'June is in her prime' should have helped, as it suggests that all the numbers in her name are prime numbers.  As the total is 17 all the numbers must be less than 10, so:
J=2; U=7; N=5; E=3  (or J=3; U=7; N=5; E=2)
Setting these numbers in the word Jane or Jean we can conclude that
16=2+A+5+3, so A=6.
Putting these numbers in the word Jenny in the same way we find Y=4.
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Interpret the hint “June is in her prime” to mean that every letter in J U N E must be a prime digit, so J, U, N, E are chosen from {2, 3, 5, 7}.  (Creative)  
2. Note June’s age is 17; the only way four distinct prime digits < 10 can sum to 17 is 2 + 3 + 5 + 7 = 17, fixing the set of values for J, U, N, E.  (Rudimentary)  
3. Assign those four digits to the letters while preserving distinctness, giving two possible permutations: (J=2, U=7, N=5, E=3) or (J=3, U=7, N=5, E=2).  (Rudimentary)  
4. Use Jane’s and Jean’s age of 16: J + A + N + E = 16.  Substituting the values for J, N, E produces A = 6.  (Rudimentary)  
5. Use Jenny’s age of 19: J + E + N + N + Y = 19.  Substituting the known digits gives Y = 4.  (Rudimentary)  
6. Check that all six letters now have different non-zero single-digit values and that each name’s letters sum to the stated age, confirming the two solutions.  (Rudimentary)

3. Assign those four digits to the letters while preserving distinctness, giving two possible permutations: (J=2, U=7, N=5, E=3) or (J=3, U=7, N=5, E=2).  (Rudimentary)

6. Check that all six letters now have different non-zero single-digit values and that each name’s letters sum to the stated age, confirming the two solutions.  (Rudimentary)']

Question: Some office workers were holding a daily pool on the number of doughnuts their boss would eat each weekday morning during March. Each person set aside funds in their desk with which to bet. Each day from Monday, March 3rd, they all bet a dollar - Kevin bet on 2, Kate on 3 and Kathy on 3.5 doughnuts. Kathy won twice as many times as Kevin, who was right once more than Kate; sometimes there was no winner. By April, they all had $20 in their desks. How much was the most anyone could have had in their desk at the beginning of March?
Hint: The pot does not accumulate if there is no winner - each person gets his "stake" back.
Human Solution:
$27
There would be 21 working days in a March where the first weekday is the third.  The combination of wins in which anyone will have lost the most money has a total of 19 wins (10 for Kathy, 5 for Kevin and 4 for Kate).  In this scenario, Kate would have lost 15 times ($15) and won 4 times ($8), for a net loss of $7.  Since she now has $20, she must have started with $27.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Count the number of weekdays in March when the first weekday is Monday, March 3 → 21 working days. (Rudimentary)  
2. Translate the win–loss conditions (Kathy wins twice Kevin; Kevin wins once more than Kate) into variables, pick the largest integer solution that keeps total wins ≤ 21, and choose 10 (Kathy), 5 (Kevin), 4 (Kate) to maximize someone’s losses. (Creative)  
3. Compute how many times Kate lost: 21 total betting days – 4 wins = 15 losses. (Rudimentary)  
4. Determine Kate’s net change: she loses $15 and gains $8 from wins, net −$7. (Rudimentary)  
5. Add the $7 net loss to the $20 each person now has to find Kate’s starting amount, $27, which is therefore the maximum anyone could have begun with. (Rudimentary)
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 5  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Count the number of weekdays in March when the first weekday is Monday, March 3 → 21 working days. (Rudimentary)  
2. Translate the win–loss conditions (Kathy wins twice Kevin; Kevin wins once more than Kate) into variables, pick the largest integer solution that keeps total wins ≤ 21, and choose 10 (Kathy), 5 (Kevin), 4 (Kate) to maximize someone’s losses. (Creative)  
3. Compute how many times Kate lost: 21 total betting days – 4 wins = 15 losses. (Rudimentary)  
4. Determine Kate’s net change: she loses $15 and gains $8 from wins, net −$7. (Rudimentary)  
5. Add the $7 net loss to the $20 each person now has to find Kate’s starting amount, $27, which is therefore the maximum anyone could have begun with. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
When world-famous Madadian philosopher Torks G'Arbage was imprisoned for being a disturbing influence and relieving himself in a public place, he was held in high esteem by his guards, many of whom had followed Torks' teachings. All four of the guards hoped that something would occur that would facilitate his escape. One evening, the guard who was on duty accidentally on purpose left the cell door open so that Torks G'Arbage could leave for distant parts.
Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape, as it was his philosophy that if you accept society's rules, you must also accept its punishments. However, the open door was considered by the Madadian authorities to be a serious matter. It was not clear which guard was on that evening. When questioned, the four guards made the following statements in their defence:
Norris McDim:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) Morris was the one who did it.
Nobby Shifty:
A) I was not the one who was on duty that evening.
B) Norris was on duty.
Morris the Daft:
A) Nobby was the one on duty that evening.
B) I hoped Torks G'Arbage would escape.
Robby O'Mental:
A) I did not leave the door open.
B) I was not surprised that Torks G'Arbage did not attempt to escape.
Considering that, in total, three statements are true and five statements are false, which guard is guilty?
Human Solution:
Robby left the door open.
The one truth given is that all 4 guards hoped that Torks G'Arbage would escape, so statement B from Morris is a truth.
There are only 3 truthful statements.
If Norris had done it, then Nobby made 2 truthful statements and Robby's statement A would be true; making a total of 4 truths, so it can't be Norris.
If Nobby had done it, statement A from Norris would be true, both of Morris's statements would be true, and Robby's statement A would be true; again a total of 4, so it can't be Nobby.
If Morris had left the cell open, both of Norris's statements would be true, as would Nobby's statement A, Morris's statement B, and Robby's statement A; a total of 5 truths.
In Robby's case, in detail:
Norris A True
B False
Nobby A True
B False
Morris A False
B True
Dave A False
B False (why did he bother to leave the
cell door open?)
Response:
Total Step Count: 6  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Observe that the story explicitly says all four guards hoped Torks G’Arbage would escape; therefore Morris’s statement B (“I hoped Torks G’Arbage would escape”) must be true.  — Creative  

2. Use the given condition that exactly three of the eight statements are true, so besides Morris B only two other statements may be true.  — Rudimentary  

3. Case 1 – Assume Norris left the door open/on duty: evaluate every statement under this assumption and find that four statements come out true; this contradicts the required total, so rule this case out.  — Rudimentary  

4. Case 2 – Assume Nobby left the door open/on duty: repeat the evaluation; again four statements turn out true, so rule this case out.  — Rudimentary  

5. Case 3 – Assume Morris left the door open/on duty: perform the evaluation; now five statements turn out true, so rule this case out.  — Rudimentary  

6. Case 4 – By elimination Robby must be the one who left the door open/on duty; check the statements and obtain exactly three truths (Norris A, Nobby A, Morris B), confirming consistency. Therefore Robby is guilty.  — Rudimentary
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 6  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 5  

Steps:  
1. Observe that the story explicitly says all four guards hoped Torks G’Arbage would escape; therefore Morris’s statement B (“I hoped Torks G’Arbage would escape”) must be true.  — Creative  

2. Use the given condition that exactly three of the eight statements are true, so besides Morris B only two other statements may be true.  — Rudimentary  

3. Case 1 – Assume Norris left the door open/on duty: evaluate every statement under this assumption and find that four statements come out true; this contradicts the required total, so rule this case out.  — Rudimentary  

4. Case 2 – Assume Nobby left the door open/on duty: repeat the evaluation; again four statements turn out true, so rule this case out.  — Rudimentary  

5. Case 3 – Assume Morris left the door open/on duty: perform the evaluation; now five statements turn out true, so rule this case out.  — Rudimentary  

6. Case 4 – By elimination Robby must be the one who left the door open/on duty; check the statements and obtain exactly three truths (Norris A, Nobby A, Morris B), confirming consistency. Therefore Robby is guilty.  — Rudimentary']

Question: I have 3 dads and 4 sisters. My immediate family (living in my house) consists of 7. Two of my sisters only have 2 dads. How is this possible?
Hint: My nephew lives with me and I'm the middle child.
Human Solution: I have a biological dad, who I don't know. An adopted dad- my sisters' dad and a step dad- who lives with me. My two younger sisters never knew my biological dad. My oldest sister (19) lives by herself. Her son lives with me, my 3 other sisters, my mom, and step dad.
Response:
Total Step Count: 5  
Creative Steps: 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:  
1. Observe that a person can legitimately have three different kinds of fathers—biological, adoptive, and step-father—so “three dads” need not be contradictory.  (Creative)  
2. State the narrator’s situation: she was born to her biological father, then legally adopted by her mother’s next partner, giving her a biological dad and an adoptive dad.  (Rudimentary)  
3. Note that the mother has since remarried; the current husband, who lives in the same house, is the narrator’s step-dad, supplying the third dad.  (Rudimentary)  
4. Explain the sisters’ dad counts: all four sisters share the adoptive dad; only the narrator (and possibly the eldest sister) has a biological dad different from theirs, so the two youngest sisters acknowledge only the adoptive dad and the step-dad—i.e., two dads.  (Rudimentary)  
5. List who actually lives in the house—narrator, three sisters, the eldest sister’s baby, mom, and step-dad—showing why the “immediate family” totals seven.  (Rudimentary)

['Total Step Count: 5  
Creative ', ' 1  
Rudimentary Steps: 4  

Steps:

2. State the narrator’s situation: she was born to her biological father, then legally adopted by her mother’s next partner, giving her a biological dad and an adoptive dad.  (Rudimentary)  
3. Note that the mother has since remarried; the current husband, who lives in the same house, is the narrator’s step-dad, supplying the third dad.  (Rudimentary)  
4. Explain the sisters’ dad counts: all four sisters share the adoptive dad; only the narrator (and possibly the eldest sister) has a biological dad different from theirs, so the two youngest sisters acknowledge only the adoptive dad and the step-dad—i.e., two dads.  (Rudimentary)  
5. List who actually lives in the house—narrator, three sisters, the eldest sister’s baby, mom, and step-dad—showing why the “immediate family” totals seven.  (Rudimentary)']

Question: A telephone number has the form ABC-DEF-GHIJ, where each letter represents a different digit. The digits in each part of the number are in decreasing order; that is, ABC, DEF, and GHIJ. Furthermore, D, E, and F are consecutive even digits; G, H, I, and J are consecutive odd digits; and A+B+C=9. What is A?
Human Solution:
The consecutive even digits DEF can be 420, 642 or 864, while the consecutive odd digits GHIJ can be 7531 or 9753.
Since A+B+C=9, none of them can be 9, and GHIJ must be 9753, and one of A, B, C is 1.
The other two add up to 8, which is obtained by 8+0.
Therefore, A, the biggest number of the three, is 8.
Response:
Total Step Count: 4  
Creative Steps: 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Use the “consecutive and decreasing” requirements to list every possible block of three even digits and four odd digits: DEF can only be 864, 642, 420; GHIJ can only be 9753, 7531.  
2. (Creative) Apply A + B + C = 9 together with the “all digits different” rule to see that none of A, B, C can be 9; therefore GHIJ must be 9753 (the only option containing 9).  
3. (Rudimentary) Observe that digit 1 has not yet been used, so one of A, B, C must be 1; hence the remaining two digits must total 8 (because 1 + ? + ? = 9).  
4. (Rudimentary) The distinct unused digits that sum to 8 and keep ABC in decreasing order are 8 and 0, giving ABC = 810; therefore A = 8.
Steps:
['Total Step Count: 4  
Creative ', ' 2  
Rudimentary Steps: 2  

Steps:  
1. (Creative) Use the “consecutive and decreasing” requirements to list every possible block of three even digits and four odd digits: DEF can only be 864, 642, 420; GHIJ can only be 9753, 7531.  
2. (Creative) Apply A + B + C = 9 together with the “all digits different” rule to see that none of A, B, C can be 9; therefore GHIJ must be 9753 (the only option containing 9).  
3. (Rudimentary) Observe that digit 1 has not yet been used, so one of A, B, C must be 1; hence the remaining two digits must total 8 (because 1 + ? + ? = 9).  
4. (Rudimentary) The distinct unused digits that sum to 8 and keep ABC in decreasing order are 8 and 0, giving ABC = 810; therefore A = 8.']

Question:
John, Pete, Tom, George, and Steve are brothers. One day, one of them broke a window. When their father asked them who did it, they gave the following answers:
John: "It was Pete or Tom."
Pete: "It was neither George nor me."
Tom: "Both of you are lying."
Steve: "No, only one of them is lying."
George: "No, Steve, you are wrong."
Then their mother added: "Three of my sons are telling the truth, but I do not believe what the two others said."
Who broke the window?
Hint: If you find it difficult to use logic alone, then use trial and error by assuming each one of the five sons broke the window, and list whether they are telling a lie or the truth.
Human Solution: By assuming that each of the five brothers broke the window and seeing how many told the truth, only Tom can be the person who broke the window.
Response:
Total Step Count: 7  
Creative Steps: 0  
Rudimentary Steps: 7  

Steps:  
1. Decide on a brute-force approach: assume each of the five brothers could have broken the window and test each assumption against the statements and the mother’s requirement of exactly three truthful statements. (Rudimentary)  
2. Assume John broke the window; evaluate the five statements under that assumption, count how many are true, observe the total is not three, so discard this possibility. (Rudimentary)  
3. Assume Pete broke the window; evaluate all statements, find the number of true statements is not three, discard. (Rudimentary)  
4. Assume Tom broke the window; evaluate all statements, find exactly three are true, keep this possibility. (Rudimentary)  
5. Assume George broke the window; test the statements, see the truth count is not three, discard. (Rudimentary)  
6. Assume Steve broke the window; test the statements, see the truth count is not three, discard. (Rudimentary)  
7. Conclude that the only assumption satisfying the mother’s “exactly three truths” condition is that Tom broke the window; therefore, Tom is the culprit. (Rudimentary)

Rudimentary Steps: 7

2. Assume John broke the window; evaluate the five statements under that assumption, count how many are true, observe the total is not three, so discard this possibility. (Rudimentary)  
3. Assume Pete broke the window; evaluate all statements, find the number of true statements is not three, discard. (Rudimentary)  
4. Assume Tom broke the window; evaluate all statements, find exactly three are true, keep this possibility. (Rudimentary)  
5. Assume George broke the window; test the statements, see the truth count is not three, discard. (Rudimentary)  
6. Assume Steve broke the window; test the statements, see the truth count is not three, discard. (Rudimentary)  
7. Conclude that the only assumption satisfying the mother’s “exactly three truths” condition is that Tom broke the window; therefore, Tom is the culprit. (Rudimentary)']

Question:
Andy dislikes the catcher. Ed's sister is engaged to the second baseman. The center fielder is taller than the right fielder. Harry and the third baseman live in the same building. One of the outfielders is either Mike or Andy. Jerry is taller than Bill. Mike is shorter than Bill. Each of them is heavier than the third baseman.
Using these facts, determine the names of the men playing the various positions on the baseball team.
